intro: Cephaloschoenus articulatus, commonly known as the articulated water milfoil, is a flowering plant in the family Haloragaceae. It is a submerged aquatic plant characterized by its whorled arrangement of leaves and its ability to form dense mats in freshwater environments. The plant has small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically clustered in spathes, and it produces small, oval fruits that are dispersed by water. It is often found in slow-moving or still freshwater habitats such as ponds, lakes, and wetlands. Its presence can indicate good water quality and is sometimes used as an indicator species for aquatic ecosystems.
